Package org.jlab.mya

Class EventStream<T extends Event>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jlab.mya.EventStream<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The Event type
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Closeable, java.lang.AutoCloseable, java.nio.channels.Channel
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    FloatEventStream, IntEventStream, MultiStringEventStream, WrappedEventStreamAdaptor
    public abstract class EventStream<T extends Event>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.nio.channels.Channel
    Provides an I/O Channel for streaming Mya events. Since Mya data is often very large it is generally a good idea to stream Mya data instead of accumulate it in memory. Therefore the fundamental behavior of this API is to stream data. You can easily accumulate the data into a collection if you believe the JVM has memory to hold it. Check the count of rows before doing that. A channel remains open until closed so generally you'll want to use a try-with-resources approach to using this class or it's subclasses. Be advised that an open EventStream holds database resources open and should be closed as quickly as possible. This class is abstract and concrete implementations provide Mya event type specific streams.

      • read

        public T read()
       throws java.io.IOException
        Read the next event from the stream. Generally you'll want to iterate over the stream using a while loop.
        Returns:
        The next event or null if End-Of-Stream reached
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If unable to read the next event

        protected abstract T rowToEvent()
                         throws java.sql.SQLException
        Read the next row of data from the ResultSet and convert it into an event.
        Returns:
        The next event
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - If unable to convert a ResultSet row to an event.
